Destiny's Child star Michelle Williams reveals she is seeking professional help for depression

The singer previously revealed she felt suicidal at times during her Destiny's Child days

View 6 Images Michelle said she had been seeking professional help (Image: WireImage)

Michelle Williams has revealed she's seeking professional help for depression.

‌



The Destiny's Child singer, who has been open about suffering from depression in the past, released a statement on Instagram on Tuesday.

‌



She wrote: "For years I have dedicated myself to increasing awareness of mental health and empowering people to recognise when it's time to seek help, support and guidance from those that love and care for your wellbeing."

‌



Michelle, 37, went on: "I recently listened to the same advice I have given to thousands around the world and sought help from a great team of healthcare professionals.

View 6 Images "If you change your mind, you can change life," she said

"Today I proudly, happily and healthily stand here as someone who will continue to always lead by example as I tirelessly advocate for the betterment of those in need."

‌



She finished: "If you change your mind, you can change life."

Her followers as well as famous faces soon praised her for speaking up.

View 6 Images Destiny's Child (L-R) Farrah Franklin, Kelly Rowland, Beyonce Knowles and Michelle Williams, appear before a performance at The Joint inside the Hard Rock Hotel & Casino July 2, 2000 (Image: Getty)

‌



Rapper Missy Elliott wrote: "I want to lift our sis up in prayer because there are so many people battling this & many trying to deal with it alone.

"Please No jokes this is REAL & as human beings let’s keep the ones who are openly dealing with it uplifted & be encouraging to them! Love u @realmichellewilliams."

Her old Destiny's Child bandmate LaTavia Roberson also sent her support.

‌



"Today you showed the world why you're a class act. Depression is real especially in our community. This is why I believe in live out loud and in colour. Keep shining love ya sis. You're not in this alone!"

Content cannot be displayed without consent

‌



Michelle first opened up about battling depression during an appearance on CBS chat show The Talk last October.

The singer told the panel she was inspired to speak out to "normalise this mental health discussion".

‌



Content cannot be displayed without consent

View 6 Images Michelle previously spoke about suffering from depression during an appearance on The Talk (Image: The Talk)

“For years, I’m in one of the top-selling female groups of all time suffering with depression,” she said, explaining she didn't understand why she felt that way when she was so successful.

‌



Michelle tried to talk to the band's manager, Beyonce's dad Mathew Knowles, but she says he couldn't comprehend her.

"When I disclosed it to our manager at the time, bless his heart, he was like, 'You all just signed a multi-million dollar deal. You’re about to go on tour. What do you have to be depressed about?'"

"So I was like, 'Oh, maybe I’m just tired,'" she said.

‌



View 6 Images Destiny's Child at the Billboard Muisc Awards in Las Vegas in 2005 (Image: REUTERS/Steve Marcus)

View 6 Images Destiny's Child reunited at Coachella earlier this year (Image: Splash News)

But from there it got worse. "It got really really bad… to the point of I was suicidal," she went on.

‌



“I was at that place where it got so dark and heavy because sometimes you feel like ‘I’m the provider, I take care of people, I’m not supposed to be feeling this way - what do I do?’ I wanted out.”

She added: "I think at the age of 25, had I had a name to what I was feeling at the time, I would have disclosed that ‘I've been suffering from depression."

Article continues below

Michelle said her experience - and others like Demi Lovato who recently released a candid documentary - inspired her to speak out about it to "normalise this mental health discussion".
